Topic.Title: Xeon breaks Calxeda's ARM in Apache benchmark

Message.Msg: I like this part of the article. "What Calxeda and any other server chip upstart (like Applied Micro or Tilera) really need to do is run some industry standard SPEC tests on their machines. SPEC CPU2006, jEnterprise 2010, and SPECpower_ssj2008 seem like good places to start. Then they need to do some real web serving and Hadoop benchmarks, which is where ARM and Tilera chips will get traction first in the server racket. And perhaps most importantly, the tests have to include the full system cost of the machine running the test and a cluster of machines (including switching costs) for supporting a horizontal workload because there is no question that Calxeda is going to have a big, big advantage here because of its integrated switching. This is why Intel has bought up Ethernet, InfiniBand, and supercomputer interconnects, after all."

Topic.Title: ALERT: INTC may be forced to cut dividend

Message.Msg: I guess I disagree with you analysis. The last time Intel was at $18, there were 6.5bil shares. Now there are 5.0bil. The number of shares have been reduced by 20%. $22 is the same as $18. EXCEPT, the last time that Intel was at $18, it had $45bil revenue and lower profits. $22 is below the equivalent $18. The dividend represents a 30% payout when Intel has said they are targetting 40%. There is a 33% margin between their payout and their target. The dividend represents an even smaller percentage of cash flow which means that the Intel board could even decide to payout more than 100% of profits in dividends without borrowing or issuing shares or .... Intel may be forced to cut the dividend but things would have to get VERY, VERY much worse before that was even thought about.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Earnings season unofficially kicks off today with reports from AA. The top line revenue numbers are likely to be the focus of this earnings season as the market tries to get a picture of economic growth. Although estimates for both Q3 and Q4 have come down in the past several months, chances of negative surprises are still high. Technically, short term momentum is bearish, but the major indexes continue to hold an intermediate term uptrend. The negative divergences between the price levels of the major indexes and their technical indicators could eventually spell trouble for the intermediate term uptrend. But until the trend breaks, it's up. have a nice day

Message.Title: While INtel warns...Sales at TSMC, UMC climb in Q3
Message.Msg: But hey... INtel fabs are ahead... and that's all that matters... ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Foundry sales at TSMC and UMC climbed strongly in the third quarter well ahead of their sales in the same period a year before. However, the picture was mixed with September sales showing slight signs of weakness. The two foundries are doing better than the overall semiconductor market, which is not expected to show growth in 2012 but sales slipped in September which may be a sign of a foundry slowdown to come. TSMC's CEO and chairman Morris Chang has previously predicted a slow down due to inventory correction in the fourth quarter of 2012 and the first quarter of 2013. For now UMC and TSMC are following similar expansive trends but with TSMC leading both in terms of absolute size and by the size of the gains it makes both quarter-on-quarter and year-on-year. While September sales at both firms declined sequentially, the third quarter showed robust sequential and annual growth for both companies. TSMC announced unconsolidated net sales for September 2012 of NT$42.82 billion (about $1.46 billion), a decrease of 12.4 percent over August 2012 and an increase of 30.3 percent over September 2011. On a consolidated basis net sales for September 2012 were approximately NT$43.35 billion (about $1.48 billion), a decrease of 12.4 percent over August 2012 and an increase of 29.8 percent over September 2011. Meanwhile UMC has announced monthly sales revenue for September of NT$9.11 billion (about $311 million) up 11.5 percent over the same month in 2011 but down 7.0 percent from August 2012. On a quarterly basis TSMC 3Q12 consolidated revenues hit a record high of NT$141.38 billion (about $4.82 billion). This was 10.4 percent ahead of the 2Q12 revenues and 32.8 percent of 3Q11 revenues. TSMC's c0nsolidated revenues for January through September 2012 totaled NT$374.94 billion, an increase of 16.3 percent compared to the same period in 2011. UMC's third quarter unconsolidated sales were NT$28.52 billion (about $973 million) up 13.3 percent on the 2Q11 and up 3.3 percent sequentially. UMC's sales for the first nine months of 2012 are $79.91 billion still down on the equivalent period in 2011, by 1.9 percent.

Message.Title: Time for Leadership Change
Message.Msg: There is no question that the global economy is a factor in Intel's (and many other companies) performance. However, one must look beyond the last few months and examine Mr. Otellini's records. In short, Mr. Otellini has been Intel's CEO for almost 8 years. He has not been successful in creating any new growth businesses for Intel. Within Intel, the move from PC to smartphone/tablets has been forseen for more than a decade and yet Intel could not capitalize on the transition. Intel continues to suggest that its silicon technologies leadership (tri-gate, 22nm, 14nm, etc.) will save the day. These messages have been parrotted by certain analysts especially those from UBS. In reality, Intel's problems are not technology or architecture based. Intel has a business model problem. The transition to smart devices and cloud computing moves the action from the PC client to the data center and the content and service providers. Yes, Intel will still benefit to some extent from the growth of data centers. But increasingly, Intel's role and value in the client (i.e., PC, smartphones, tablets, etc.) are eroding. This is where the majority of the volume and brand value reside. With this erosion, Intel's brand value is also impacted. Intel needs a major make-over. And Mr. Otellini is not the right leader to take Intel back to a growth path. The Board should act now!

Message.Title: Which is worse? Romney's wife and a pony or.........
Message.Msg: WASHINGTON — House Speaker Nancy Pelosi paid her husband's real estate and investment firm nearly $100,000 from her political action committee over the past decade, a practice that she voted to ban last year and that her party condemned as part of the "culture of corruption" when Republicans did it. The Washington Times is reporting that the California Democrat's husband, Paul F. Pelosi, owns Financial Leasing Services Inc., which has received $99,000 in rent, utilities and accounting fees from the speaker's "PAC to the Future" over the PAC's nine-year history. Last year, Pelosi supported a bill that would have banned members of Congress from putting spouses on their campaign staffs. The bill banned not only direct payments by congressional campaign committees and PACs to spouses for services including consulting and furndraising, but also "indirect compensation," such as payments to companies that employ spouses. The bill passed the House in a voice vote but died in a Senate committee. Last week, Pelosi's office defended the payments, saying they were legal because she is compensating her husband at fair market value for the work his firm has performed for the PAC. Ethical watchdogs called Pelosi's arrangement "problematic."

Topic.Title: 22nm SoC on schedule - end of 2013

Message.Msg: I think most people who talk about power consumption have no idea waht they are talking about because few have never designed a chip before or worked on silicon technology. Intel likes to compare "active" power vs. other chips or as part of the overall system power. However, in mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets, one of the key issue is standby power and leakage. That's the area Intel has a serious disadvantage. The fundamental issue is how Intel tunes its designs and silicon processes to achieve performance vs. power saving. As such, Intel's chips are higher perforamnce and competitive on "active" power. In reality, unless you are constantly encoding/transcodinfg video on your smartphone or tablet, you don't need this kind of high performance and the penalty of the higher active power. What you need is a very low standby power (low leakage) so that your battery can last a full day. Can Intel produce such a technology and design? Of course....but Intel has not made this a priority...yet! ARM, together with TSMC/Samsung, have. In summary, it is not a question of a 22nm SoC. Yes, a smaller geometry chip is (usually) lower power because it is a smaller chip. But much more important, it is how you design and target the technology.

Topic.Title: 22nm SoC on schedule - end of 2013

Message.Msg: going from Sandy Beach to Ivy Beach? Internal Intel codenames derive from existing geographic places in North America. A rare exception is “Sandy Bridge,” the codename for Intel’s second-generation Core processor. In Intel’s so-called “tick-tock” model, “Ivy Bridge” is a “tick,” an advance in manufacturing process technology, to the ‘tock” that was the “Sandy Bridge” microarchitecture. To understand how “Ivy Bridge” got its name, it’s helpful to look back at how the company came up with “Sandy Bridge.” Harsat, who is based in Haifa, Israel, originally named the “Sandy Bridge” microarchitecture “Gesher,” the Hebrew word for “bridge.” The rationale, which he admits bypassed the geographical criteria for codenames, was that his team was responsible for defining a new generation of microarchitecture, or as Harsat saw it, “a bridge into the future.”

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: Selling in the technology momentum names was disconcerting. Both the NASDAQ and the Russell 2000 indexes broke support near their September lows suggesting a potential intermediate trend change to the downside. The good news is that both the DJIA and the S&P 500 held up relatively well and the volume was light. The overall uptrend stayed intact. The S&P 500 has support in the 1430 area, its late September low, followed by the 1425 area, its 50-day moving average. As long as the earnings aren't too bad, expect dip buyers to step in when those support areas are first tested. Overall, expect more choppy moves with a downside bias as stocks aren't oversold yet. It's a market for traders to buy on dips and sell on rips. have a nice evening

Topic.Title: This is a $19 stock

Message.Msg: Stable consistent money is in enterprise not cell phones which will see diminishing margins over the next 10 years due to competition from Nvidia, INTC, and Qualcom. ARM is way too slow to ever be used in enterprise except maybe for very small businesses who want a micro-server. Big business will be 100x better off with a powerful chip and 15 virtual servers in one box than 15 separate ARM servers. Also, Intel can make (and is making) a competitor to arm. Once MSFT ports their software to ARM it will more than likely also run on the INTC chip (as well as snapdragons and tegras) thus providing instant usability. INTC however will never lose their enterprise space to any of the above competitors. The only competitor in enterprise is AMD and they are drowning in debt.

Message.Title: Wall Street Continues to Beat Tech Like a Drum
Message.Msg: Wall Street continues to beat not just Intel but most of tech like a drum. They will use money and leverage to drive it down below any sensible valuation and then they will ride it back up. When the smoke clears a whole lot of average investors will be separated from their money and will exit the stock market forever. If something isn't done to protect the average investor from the big money #$%$, the integrity of the markets will be permanently damaged. There are already quite a few who think the game is rigged and with good reason. The only answer is to support reasonable regulation of Wall Street and reasonable disclosure of hedge fund trading activity. Write the SEC, your representatives in Washington and the media. Do it often. Pretty much all Intel longs just sat and did nothing while Wall Street was viciously assaulting the stock price. Maybe when you lose enough money to the #$%$, you'll be willing to make an effort to rein the #$%$ in. Your call...
